issue.title: use the sharedLockFreePool as default pool instead of allocating a new one

repository.name: jackson-core
repository.description: Core part of Jackson that defines Streaming API as well as basic shared abstractions

issue.body: At the moment jackson allocates a new pool every time the default pool is asked. I believe it would be more correct to always reuse the shared one also because the (useless?) creation of a new one is not only causing [this issue in quarkus](https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/pull/39739), but even worse is very likely the main cause of the performance problem reported [here](https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-module-scala/issues/672).

issue.title: Jackson LockFreePool recycler pool causes memory issues

repository.name: trino
repository.description: Official repository of Trino, the distributed SQL query engine for big data, formerly known as PrestoSQL (https://trino.io)

issue.body:
After upgrade Trino from 409 to 443 we started to have memory issues. Some workers disappear from the cluster due to intensive major GC. In the logs we can see messages like:
```
INFO    Notification Thread     io.airlift.stats.JmxGcMonitor   Major GC: application 61ms, stopped 9353ms: 91.59GB -> 91.13GB
```
On the graphs we can see memory starvation:
![image](https://github.com/trinodb/trino/assets/1793410/ea3de493-3823-4dbd-b74c-ef6c90a9dd7e)

Heap dump analisys shows it comes from [JsonUtil#OBJECT_MAPPED_UNORDERED](https://github.com/trinodb/trino/blob/443/core/trino-main/src/main/java/io/trino/util/JsonUtil.java#L113). It creates `JsonFactory` with default implementation of `RecyclerPool` which is [LockFreePool](https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-core/blob/jackson-core-2.17.0/src/main/java/com/fasterxml/jackson/core/util/JsonRecyclerPools.java#L29). This implementation is relatively young, has some concerns and is considered not to be used as default https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-core/issues/1256

![image](https://github.com/trinodb/trino/assets/1793410/f1cc5e73-f58e-49c8-9bd3-0038359970d9)

We have change the factory below to use [JsonRecyclerPools.threadLocalPool()](https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-core/blob/jackson-core-2.17.0/src/main/java/com/fasterxml/jackson/core/util/JsonRecyclerPools.java#L38)

https://github.com/trinodb/trino/blob/f0d5b0febd2c06fc79a63dec0c702a224e31c248/core/trino-main/src/main/java/io/trino/util/JsonUtil.java#L118-L121

I'm not sure it's the best implementation for Trino but now we can't reproduce the issue.

labels.name: no-release-notes
labels.description: This pull request does not require release notes entry

repository.name: trino
repository.description: Official repository of Trino, the distributed SQL query engine for big data, formerly known as PrestoSQL (https://trino.io)

issue.title: Performance regression with 2.17.x

repository.name: jackson-module-scala
repository.description: Add-on module for Jackson (https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson) to support Scala-specific datatypes

issue.body:
Both 2.17.0 and 2.17.0-rc1 are affected when small messages (less than 100 bytes) are parsed or serialized in multiple threads using the same object mapper instance.

The problem exists when parsing bigger messages but the performance difference is smaller.

All libraries that use the latest version of jackson library under the hood are affected: json4s, play-json, weePickle, etc.

Here are results of benchmarks that parse and serialize 62-byte and 1185-byte messages (`ADTReading`/`ADTWriting` and `ArrayOfEnumADTsReading`/`ArrayOfEnumADTsWriting` accordingly) on Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-11700 @ 2.50GHz (max 4.90 GHz) with DDR4-3200 using 16 threads:


Steps to reproduce:
1. Download binaries of [async-profiler](https://github.com/async-profiler/async-profiler/releases/tag/v3.0) and unpack them into `/opt/async-profiler`
1. `git clone https://github.com/plokhotnyuk/jsoniter-scala`
2. `cd jsoniter-scala`
3. `sbt -java-home /usr/lib/jvm/jdk-21 jsoniter-scala-benchmarkJVM/clean 'jsoniter-scala-benchmarkJVM/jmh:run -prof "async:dir=target/async-reports;interval=1000000;output=flamegraph;libPath=/opt/async-profiler/lib/libasyncProfiler.so" -jvmArgsAppend "-XX:+UnlockDiagnosticVMOptions -XX:+DebugNonSafepoints" --p size=128 -t 16 -wi 10 -i 10 ADT'`

The issue exists when tested on other JVMs (GraalVM Community, Oracle GraalVM) and with other garbage collectors (G1GC, ZGC)

Here are flame-graphs of async-profiler reports for `ADTWriting.jacksonScala` benchmark:

### 2.16.2
![image](https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-module-scala/assets/890289/65687745-794d-4c43-82ed-402a1d22c0f8)
### 2.17.0
![image](https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-module-scala/assets/890289/7da3de36-b552-4369-8dbd-588a3857e940)

For json4s and play-json libraries performance could dynamically slowing down in about 1000x times:
```
[info] # Warmup Iteration   1: 498097.603 ops/s
[info] # Warmup Iteration   2: 1396602.529 ops/s
[info] # Warmup Iteration   3: 1390047.351 ops/s
[info] # Warmup Iteration   4: 1397460.036 ops/s
[info] # Warmup Iteration   5: 548693.538 ops/s
[info] # Warmup Iteration   6: 467155.766 ops/s
[info] # Warmup Iteration   7: 308437.551 ops/s
[info] # Warmup Iteration   8: 299814.921 ops/s
[info] # Warmup Iteration   9: 120140.861 ops/s
[info] # Warmup Iteration  10: 16015.216 ops/s
[info] Iteration   1: 6210.625 ops/s
[info] Iteration   2: 3199.072 ops/s
[info] Iteration   3: 9214.890 ops/s
[info] Iteration   4: 6565.308 ops/s
[info] Iteration   5: 1545.670 ops/s
[info] Iteration   6: 9597.542 ops/s
[info] Iteration   7: 6781.583 ops/s
[info] Iteration   8: 12569.237 ops/s
[info] Iteration   9: 5324.412 ops/s
[info] Iteration  10: 7944.598 ops/s
```

Could be [using of `ThreadLocal` for cashing of object mappers](https://github.com/plokhotnyuk/jsoniter-scala/compare/master...workaround-for-perf-issues) be an acceptable workaround for this issue?

Is any workaround where we can explicitly define initial size of underlying buffers to be suitable for using with other libraries like play-json and weePickle?

issue.title: Figure out why `LockFreePool` appears to cause unintended object retention (~= memory leak)

repository.name: jackson-core
repository.description: Core part of Jackson that defines Streaming API as well as basic shared abstractions

issue.body:
Based on report problem like:

* https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-module-scala/issues/672
* https://github.com/trinodb/trino/issues/21356

it looks as if the new recycler pool default (see #1117) -- Lock-free Pool -- results in (at least in some cases) unbounded increasing memory retention over time. From symptoms it would appear as if actual releases to pool happened more often than succesful reuse from the pool, as otherwise 2 operations should generally balance out over time (resulting in maximum pool size relative to maximum concurrent use).

We need to figure out what could cause such behavior, or if not, what is the root cause of observed problems.

In the meantime we also will need to do #1256 to allow use of 2.17(.1) without this issue.

rename.from: Revert #1117: change default recycler pool back to `threadLocalPool()`
rename.to: Revert #1117: change default recycler pool back to `threadLocalPool()` OR change to `concurrentDequePool`

rename.from: Revert #1117: change default recycler pool back to `threadLocalPool()` OR change to `concurrentDequePool`
rename.to: Revert #1117: change default recycler pool back to `threadLocalPool()`

issue.title: Change default recycler pool to `newConcurrentDequePool()` in 2.18

repository.name: jackson-core
repository.description: Core part of Jackson that defines Streaming API as well as basic shared abstractions

issue.body:
(note: follow-up to #1256)

Altho we will revert back to `ThreadLocalPool` for 2.17.1 and rest of 2.17.x, we do want to move away in 2.18.
Let's use "ConcurrentDequePool" (via `JsonRecyclerPools.newConcurrentDequePool()`) as that seems to behave better and have otherwise similar approach as shared-lock-pool, but without potentially failing acquire that can lead to imbalanced handling & ever-growing pool.

rename.from: Revert #1117: change default recycler pool back to `threadLocalPool()`
rename.to: Revert #1117: change default recycler pool back to `threadLocalPool()` for 2.17.1

issue.title: How to change default RecyclerPool for 2.17.0 ?

repository.name: jackson-core
repository.description: Core part of Jackson that defines Streaming API as well as basic shared abstractions

issue.body:
Maybe there are some memory leak issue with 2.17.0. We are running OpenSearch 2.14.0 which use jackson-core 2.17.0.
I want to try change default RecyclerPool to see if jvm heap will back to normal.

Thanks

issue.title: Backport: Bump com.fasterxml.jackson:jackson-bom from 2.17.0 to 2.17.1 (#19256)
issue.body:
Backport of #19256

Several projects reported memory issues related to Jackson version 2.17.0. See e.g. [here](https://github.com/opensearch-project/OpenSearch/issues/13927) and [here](https://github.com/trinodb/trino/issues/21356).
The issue has been [fixed in Jackson version 2.17.1](https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-core/issues/1256).

We haven't received any reports of Graylog being affected, but as a safety measure, we are backporting the Jackson update to the fixed version.

Bumps [com.fasterxml.jackson:jackson-bom](https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-bom) from 2.17.0 to 2.17.1.

repository.name: elasticsearch
repository.description: Free and Open Source, Distributed, RESTful Search Engine
